questions.text: After administering the patch test to a 10-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis, when should you schedule his return for patch removal? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48 hours

 

The Gold standard Diagnostic test for Airborne contact dermatitis (ABCD) & Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is a patch test. 

 

Patch testing:

 

  • It is a method used to determine if a specific substance causes allergic inflammation of a patient's skin.
  • It is typically indicated for patients with suspected allergic contact dermatitis.
  • The test involves the application of various substances in small chambers or patches to the skin, usually on the back.
  • After the application of a patch test, the patches are generally removed at 48 hours (2 days), and an initial reading is taken.
  • This timeframe allows for the elicitation of a Type IV or delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is the basis of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • However, readings at 48 hours may not be sufficient to detect all reactions, and thus an additional reading at 96 hours is often recommended.
  • The additional reading helps to identify late reactions, which could otherwise be missed if only the 48-hour reading is considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours

 

  • This timeframe is too short for most delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions to occur.
  • Removing the patches at 24 hours would likely result in missing many positive reactions.

 

Option B. 72 hours

 

  • It is not typically when the patches are first removed.
  • The patches are usually removed at 48 hours, and the skin is then inspected for any reactions.

 

Option D. 96 hours

 

  • This is a common time for a follow-up reading and not the initial removal of the patches.
  • Some protocols suggest readings at this time to ensure that late-appearing reactions are not missed.

 

The image below shows a patch test:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Rooks textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.23

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 406

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3900336/

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of recurrent lesions on lips as shown in the image below, which is associated with fever. What is the characteristic feature seen in Tzanck smear? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multinucleated giant cells

 

The patient presents with recurrent vesicular lesions on the lips associated with fever, which is characteristic of Herpes labialis caused by the Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). This condition is often triggered by fever and is hence also called a "fever blister" or "cold sores."

 

Another condition with recurrent lesions at the same site, typically triggered by a particular medication each time the patient is exposed to it is “Fixed Drug Eruption”. But here the initial appearance of vesicles on the lips is noted. These vesicles are prone to rupture. Once ruptured, the vesicles transform into erosions and ulcers with polycyclic margins, characteristic of herpes labialis. A history of fever is important as it often triggers these outbreaks.

 

On a Tzanck smear, the characteristic finding for Herpes labialis is the presence of multinucleated giant cells and acantholytic cells. These multinucleate giant cells are formed by the fusion of infected cells, leading to the appearance of multiple nuclei within a single cell. The Tzanck smear is specifically used in dermatology to diagnose viral infections, particularly Herpes simplex and Varicella-zoster.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Henderson Patterson bodies: These are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum, a viral infection caused by a poxvirus. These are not associated with Herpes labialis and are not found on a Tzanck smear for this condition.

 

 

Option C. Acanthocytes: These are spiny red blood cells that are typically seen in liver diseases such as cirrhosis and in certain neurological disorders. They are not related to the findings in a Tzanck smear or Herpes labialis. Although "acantholytic cells" can also be seen in Herpes labialis, these are different from acanthocytes.

 

 

Option D. Owl eye appearance: This term describes the characteristic appearance of cells infected by Cytomegalovirus (CMV), where the nucleus shows a large inclusion giving it an "owl eye" look. This is not a feature of Herpes labialis and would not be seen on a Tzanck smear for this condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear is the characteristic diagnostic feature for Herpes labialis (HSV-1).

questions.text: The clinical finding in the 10-year-old boy includes fever, joint pain, and a hand lesion as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules - Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

  • Juvenile dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease affecting the skin and muscles. It typically presents in children with a characteristic skin rash and muscle weakness.
  • Gottron's papules are distinctive red or violet, raised, scaly lesions seen over knuckles (dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints), elbows, knees, and other extensor surfaces, highly suggestive of dermatomyositis.
  • The combination of fever, joint pain, and Gottron's papules strongly indicates juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Other features associated with Dermatomyositis are:

 

  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign: seen in the above image

 

  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual telangiectasias: enlarged capillaries in the nail folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid nodules - Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis:

 

  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder causing chronic joint inflammation in children.
  • Rheumatoid nodules are firm, painless, subcutaneous nodules that usually occur in areas of pressure but are not typically seen in the hands in this form.
  • The lesion in the image doesn't match the typical appearance of rheumatoid nodules.

 

Option C Sclerodactyly - Systemic sclerosis:

 

  • Systemic sclerosis is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and hardening (scleroderma).
  • Sclerodactyly refers to thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers and hands, leading to a claw-like appearance.
  • The lesion shown doesn't indicate the skin thickening or tightness characteristic of sclerodactyly.

 

Option D Mechanic's hand - Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease affecting multiple organ systems.
  • Mechanic's hand is a sign associated more with dermatomyositis than SLE, characterized by rough, cracked skin on the sides of the fingers, mimicking the hands of a manual labourer.
  • The presentation of mechanic's hand in SLE is less common and the symptoms described do not align well with SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case involving fever, joint pain, and hand lesions in a child, the presence of Gottron's papules is indicative of Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53 page no 53.1-53.12

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page 2820-2821

questions.text: Identify the drug used to treat the condition shown below: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anti-tubercular therapy

 

  • The image showing a plaque with one margin extending & other margin healing with scarring (Asymmetrical lesion), this favors to the diagnosis of lupus vulgaris, which is treated using anti-tubercular drugs.
  • It is the most common cutaneous tuberculosis in adults in India.
  • It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity.
  • Granulomas with little to no caseation can be seen on histology.

 

Lupus Vulgaris

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of skin TB seen in patients with moderate immunity to TB bacilli
  • It is seen more common in females.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • It occurs due to hematogenous, lymphatic, or contiguous spread from elsewhere in the body, or from exogenous inoculation. It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity, hence Paucibacillary.

 

Clinical features

 

  • It presents as single or few lesions which are well demarcated, annular plaques which extend centrifugally. Periphery show erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as apple jelly nodules as seen in the image below.

 

 

  •  They are most commonly seen in buttocks, upper extremities, and face. Center is depigmented with paper-thin scar with nodules.
  • Papules may recur on the scarred areas, which enlarge and coalesce. This leads to the formation of large, firm, elevated plaques.

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Histologic examination & a positive culture for M. tuberculosis/ bovis confirm the diagnosis
  • Most prominent histopathologic feature: Typical granulomas with scanty or absent caseation.

 

Complication

 

  • Secondary scarring & squamous cell carcinomas may develop rarely.

 

Treatment:

Anti-tubercular drugs.

 

CLASSIFICATION OF CUTANEOUS TUBERCULOSIS IS BASED ON THE MODE OF ACQUISITION:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical steroids therapy:

  • This is not the appropriate treatment for lupus vulgaris.
  • Topical steroids are used for inflammatory conditions, and while they may reduce inflammation and symptoms temporarily, they do not address the underlying mycobacterial infection that causes lupus vulgaris.

 

Option B. Anti-leprosy treatment:

  • Although leprosy is also caused by a mycobacterium (Mycobacterium leprae) and anti-leprosy drugs are used to treat it, the clinical features described do not match leprosy.
  • Moreover, the treatment regimens for leprosy and tuberculosis are different.

 

Option C. Anti-fungal therapy:

  • Fungal infections can present with skin lesions, but the description of the lesion as characteristic of lupus vulgaris does not fit a fungal infection.
  • Anti-fungal therapy would not be effective against mycobacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis characterized by irregular plaques that show progression at one margin and healing with scarring at another, and to understand that the appropriate treatment is a multi-drug anti-tubercular therapy regimen.

 

References:

 

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 27.21-27.23, 32.35-32.36, 33.44-33.45

questions.text:
The diagnosis for a 23-year-old patient presenting with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region of the head, and exhibiting histological findings of hair loss with haemorrhage into the follicular areas and mild perinuclear lymphocytic infiltrate, is what? 
(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichotillomania

 

From the given clinical features & histopathological features, diagnosis is Trichotillomania (TTM) / Trichotillosis / Hair pulling disorder.

 

Clinical features suggestive of Trichotillomania in the clinical vignette:

 

  • The clinical history revealing non scarring alopecia in the vertex region (Hair pulling and plucking is commonest from the scalp)
  • No signs of inflammation
  • Perifollicular hemorrhage

 

Diagnostic criteria for TTM include:

 

  • Recurrent pulling out of one’s own hair resulting in non-scarring hair loss.
  • An increasing sense of tension immediately before pulling out the hair or when attempting to resist the behaviour.
  • Pleasure, gratification, or relief when pulling out the hair.
  • The disturbance is not better accounted for by another mental disorder.
  • The disturbance provokes clinically marked distress and/or impairment in occupational, social, or other areas of functioning.
  • Histopathology: No / Minimal inflammation
  • Peribulbar hemorrhage - due to trauma from plucking of hair.
  • intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhage and intrafollicular pigment casts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alopecia areata:

 

  • While it is characterized by non-scarring alopecia and can have lymphocytic infiltrate around the hair follicles, the hemorrhage is not a typical feature.
  • Generally presents as well-defined patches of hair loss.

 

Option B. Telogen effluvium:

 

  • It manifests as a diffuse or generalized hair shedding from the entire scalp rather than localized patches.
  • It's commonly due to stress, certain medications, or illnesses.
  • Histopathology would not typically show hemorrhage or the specific perinuclear infiltrate described.

 

Option C. Tinea infection:

 

  • Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp.
  • It usually presents with scaling and possibly broken-off hairs.
  • Histological examination would show evidence of fungal elements (hyphae and spores) rather than hemorrhage or lymphocytic infiltrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young patient with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region and histological findings of hair loss with follicular hemorrhage and mild lymphocytic infiltrate, the diagnosis is likely Trichotillomania.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 86 & 89, page nos 86.17 & 89.31

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no: 1695

questions.text: A male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, presents with blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also experienced similar issues and unfortunately passed away at the age of 2 weeks. What is the probable diagnosis?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa

 

  • The male baby's current condition, characterized by blisters appearing in areas of friction, along with a similar history in a sibling, strongly suggests a diagnosis of a genetic condition called as epidermolysis bullosa congenita.
  • Epidermolysis bullosa is a mechano-bullous disease where blisters develop in response to mechanical trauma, often occurring in regions prone to friction such as the hands, feet, elbows, and knees.

 

 

Various types of Epidermolysis bullosa (EB) & Defects associated with them:

 

 

Other options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The likely diagnosis in a neonate presenting with blistering at areas of friction, especially with a similar family history and early demise in a sibling, is Epidermolysis bullosa, a genetic condition causing extremely fragile skin leading to blister formation with minimal trauma.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 71 Page no 71.4-71.16

questions.text: A female patient with a BMI of 35 kg/m2 presents to you with a skin lesion in the axilla as shown below. Which of the following condition is she most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic syndrome

 

  • The skin lesion shown in the image of axilla with velvety textured skin is indicative of Acanthosis nigricans. In this case, the patient is most likely suffering from Metabolic syndrome based on the diagnosis.

 

Acanthosis nigricans

  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism:

  • Hypothyroidism primarily manifests with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, bradycardia, alopecia and dry skin. It doesn't typically lead to velvety skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans.

 

Option C. Addison’s disease:

  • Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, leads to symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, salt craving, and hyperpigmentation. However, the hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's is more diffuse and not restricted to velvety changes in the axilla.

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism:

  • This condition primarily results from an overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to elevated calcium levels in the blood. Symptoms include kidney stones, bone pain, and fatigue. Skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans are not a typical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References –

Harrisons principle s of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 390, 2933,2934, 2936, 2970, 2971, 3086, 3150, 3151, 3154, 3155, 3156, 3173, 3175

Current Medical Diagnosis & Treatment 2022 Page no 1157

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 147, Page no 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 391

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zoster (shingles)

 

A maculopapular rash is not seen in zoster (shingles).

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rubella: Presents with a maculopapular rash as shown in the image below, which consists of minute, discrete macules.

 

 

  • The rash appears within 24 hours of onset of prodromal symptoms.

 

Option C. Dengue (during febrile phase): Dengue fever can present with a maculopapular rash during its febrile phase.

 

Option D. Measles: Measles is characterized by fever and a maculopapular skin rash, which is accompanied by immune clearance of measles virus (MV)-infected cells

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zoster (shingles) does not present with a maculopapular rash but rather with a painful, vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. In contrast, rubella, dengue during the febrile phase, and measles are classic causes of maculopapular rashes.
 

 

Ref- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106
Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

choices.text: Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

questions.text: A young male, aged 24, has presented with asymptomatic scaly skin lesions on his back, symmetrically distributed. The provided images showcase the lesions. Can you identify the pattern of these skin lesions & the specific disease? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Collarette scale - Christmas tree pattern - Pityriasis rosea

 

Given clinical scenario and images showing Collarette scale (Herald patch) and Christmas tree pattern distributed lesions, points to a diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea.

 

PITYRIASIS ROSEA

 

  • Acute: Self-limiting (6-12 weeks) disease.
  • Etiology: Most common viral trigger is HHV 7.
  • Asymptomatic >> mild pruritus may be present.
  • Features:
    • 1st lesion: Herald patch / mother patch 1-2 weeks later.
    • Secondary lesions: Scaly papules → oval annular plaques → mild pigmentary changes → fades slowly in 6-12 weeks.
  • Distribution of Lesions: Christmas tree pattern (Downwards & outwards from the spine along the lines of Langer).
  • Treatment: Counsel, self-limiting 6-12 weeks.

 

Other Options

 

Option B: Wickham’s striae - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: Lichen Planus is characterized by pruritic, purple, polygonal papules and plaques. Wickham’s striae are white, lacy lines seen on the surface of lesions, typically not featuring a Christmas tree pattern.

 

 

Option C: Christmas tree pattern - Lichen Planus

 

  • Incorrect: While Lichen Planus can have a wide distribution, it does not typically display a Christmas tree pattern, which is specifically associated with Pityriasis rosea.

 

Option D: Wornoff ring – Seborrheic Dermatitis

 

  • Incorrect: Seborrheic Dermatitis typically presents with oily, scaly patches on the scalp, face, and other sebaceous areas, not as a Christmas tree pattern on the back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Pityriasis rosea is primarily based on the characteristic appearance and distribution of the rash, with the herald patch and subsequent Christmas tree pattern being hallmark features. Awareness of this pattern and the self-limiting nature of the disease helps in reassuring patients and managing expectations regarding the course of the condition

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a persistent skin rash. Initially, she had an itchy, ring-shaped rash that partially resolved with a topical ointment. However, within a week of discontinuing the treatment, the itching returned and the rash spread. She denies any new products or environmental exposures. Physical examination reveals poorly demarcated, erythematous plaques with slight scaling scattered over her face, as shown in the image below. There are no vesicles, pustules, or signs of systemic illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tinea incognito

 

Explanation:

 

Tinea incognito is a fungal infection that has been altered by the inappropriate use of topical corticosteroids. This condition often presents with atypical features compared to a classic dermatophyte infection. The history of initial improvement with a topical ointment (likely a corticosteroid) followed by a return and worsening of symptoms after discontinuation is characteristic of tinea incognito. The poorly demarcated erythematous plaques with slight scaling observed on physical examination support this diagnosis. The use of corticosteroids suppresses the inflammation and itching temporarily but allows the fungal infection to proliferate more aggressively once the treatment is stopped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea corporis: This typically presents with well-demarcated, annular, scaly plaques with central clearing and an active border, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Tinea cruris: Usually affects the groin area and is also characterized by well-demarcated borders and central clearing, which is not consistent with the facial distribution and poorly demarcated lesions observed here.

 

Option D. Tinea capitis: This affects the scalp and hair, presenting with scaly patches, hair loss, and sometimes black dots. The facial distribution and presentation described do not match tinea capitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea incognito should be suspected when a dermatophyte infection worsens after the use of topical steroids, leading to atypical presentation and distribution of the lesions.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman who presented with complaints of fever and joint pain develops the following lesion on her nose after a few days of taking NSAIDs. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chikungunya

 

  • The patient's medical history is indicative of a potential diagnosis of Chikungunya (CKG) infection.
  • Chikungunya is a mosquito-borne viral illness presenting with fever, joint pain, and potential rash.

 

 

Fig: Nose pigmentation

 

IMAGE DEPICTING CHIK SIGN

 

  • It can cause skin hyperpigmentation, especially on the nose and cheeks, known as the "Chik sign."
  • The "Chik sign" is distinctive to Chikungunya and is not usually seen with other viral infections.
  • The nose pigmentation may last three to six months post-infection, aiding in clinical and retrospective diagnosis.
  • This pigmentation pattern serves as a clinical marker for Chikungunya infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melasma:

 

Typically presents as symmetric brown patches on the face, especially the cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often triggered by sun exposure or hormonal changes, such as pregnancy or use of oral contraceptives.

 

Option B. Fixed drug eruption (FDE):

 

  • It is a type of allergic reaction to medications. It presents as well-demarcated, round, or oval patches of redness and swelling that can later become brown.
  • However, FDEs are typically recurrent in the same location when the offending drug is taken again, and the presentation isn't specifically associated with the symptoms described.

 

Option C. Dengue:

 

  • While dengue fever is also a mosquito-borne viral infection leading to symptoms like fever, headache, and joint pains, it does not typically result in brownish pigmentation on the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of fever, body ache, and joint pain, followed by the development of brownish pigmentation on the nose, Chikungunya is the probable diagnosis, as it can present with persistent joint pain and hyperpigmentation, particularly in regions where the virus is endemic.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child complains of mild painful swelling over the scalp for 3 months as shown in the image below. He also has a pet dog at his home. What is the diagnosis of the given condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Kerion

 

  • The case of a young boy coming into contact with a zoophilic organism and displaying symptoms of a boggy inflammatory mass, accompanied by thick crusting and matting of hair, indicates a possible diagnosis of kerion.
  • Kerion is an intense inflammatory form of tinea capitis, caused by dermatophytes that have an affinity for animals (pet dog clue).

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms - T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount

 

Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum à Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton à Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furuncle:

  • Description: Also known as a boil, a furuncle is a deep folliculitis, an infection of the hair follicle.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Furuncles are typically more localized and painful and would not be described as "boggy." Also, they don’t have a direct association with having a pet dog.

 

Option B. Epidermoid cyst:

  • Description: These are benign cysts originating from the epidermis. They are filled with keratin and have a characteristic central punctum as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Epidermoid cysts are typically non-painful unless infected. They do not usually present as boggy swellings and are not related to having a pet.

 

Option D. Folliculitis:

  • Description: Folliculitis is the inflammation or infection of one or more hair follicles.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Folliculitis on the scalp would typically present as multiple small, itchy, and red pustules. It wouldn't create a boggy swelling as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kerion is a boggy, tender scalp swelling associated with hair loss and potentially linked to animal exposure, indicative of a fungal infection rather than a bacterial cause like furuncle or folliculitis, or a benign lesion such as an epidermoid cyst.

 

Reference: 

 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11

questions.text: Which component of cement causes allergic contact dermatitis among construction workers in India? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chromate

 

  • It is a component of chromium, is commonly used in the manufacturing of cement and is a well-known cause of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) among construction workers due to their frequent and prolonged exposure to wet cement.
  • Chromate can cause ACD through a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • When cement containing chromate comes into contact with the skin, particularly in the presence of moisture, the chromate can leach out and result in sensitization and subsequent dermatitis.
  • Allergic contact dermatitis is an inflammatory response to an allergen that only manifests as an eruption in people who have already been sensitized to the allergen.
  • The diagnosis of ACD is made by Patch test with the culprit substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalt: Cobalt is less commonly a cause of ACD in construction workers compared to chromate. Cobalt may be present in tools or dyes, but not typically in cement.

 

Option B. Nickel: Nickel is a well-known cause of ACD, often associated with exposure to nickel-containing jewellery or clothing items, not with cement.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron, while common in construction materials, is not a frequent cause of ACD. It is not known to be an allergen that would typically induce contact dermatitis.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among construction workers in India, allergic contact dermatitis is most commonly caused by chromate in cement, due to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction when chromate comes into contact with the skin.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 128 page no 128.2-14

Online source: https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/2965911

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of joint pain and stiffness, primarily in her hands and feet. She mentions that the pain is worse in the morning and improves with activity. On examination, there is noticeable swelling of the distal interphalangeal joints. She also has silvery, scaly plaques on her elbows and knees. Her family history is positive for psoriasis. There is no history of gastrointestinal symptoms or eye inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psoriatic Arthritis

 

Explanation:

 

Psoriatic arthritis (PsA) is characterized by joint pain and stiffness, which is often worse in the morning and improves with activity, indicating the presence of morning stiffness. The involvement of distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints is particularly notable in PsA and is a distinguishing feature. The presence of silvery, scaly plaques on the skin, especially on the extensor surfaces like elbows and knees, aligns with the diagnosis of psoriasis, a common comorbidity in PsA. Additionally, a positive family history for psoriasis strongly supports this diagnosis.

 

 

The swelling observed in the DIP joints can be specifically referred to as dactylitis, which is a hallmark of PsA. This form of arthritis is also known as seronegative arthritis, meaning it is negative for rheumatoid factor, distinguishing it from rheumatoid arthritis. PsA is an erosive arthritis that can lead to joint damage if not properly managed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis: Typically involves the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints rather than the DIP joints. It is usually seropositive, meaning it often tests positive for rheumatoid factor. The skin lesions described are not characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option B. Gout: Usually presents with acute onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling, often in the first metatarsophalangeal joint (big toe). It does not typically involve silvery, scaly plaques or have a family history of psoriasis.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints rather than the peripheral joints like the DIP joints. It also does not present with psoriasis or skin plaques as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriatic arthritis often presents with joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the distal interphalangeal joints, along with characteristic silvery, scaly skin plaques and a family history of psoriasis.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Acanthosis nigricans

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is the illness depicted in the image.
  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pityriasis rotunda

 

  • Description: This is a rare skin condition characterized by large, round patches of dry, scaly skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Melasma

 

  • Description: Melasma is characterized by brown to gray-brown patches, mainly on the face (cheeks, bridge of the nose, forehead, chin, and above the upper lip). It's often called the "mask of pregnancy."

 

Option C. Dermatomyositis

 

  • Description: An inflammatory muscle disease, dermatomyositis presents with skin rash and muscle weakness. The rash is often reddish or purple, seen on the eyelids, knuckles, elbows, knees, and sometimes the chest and back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 147, Page nos 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology 3rd edition Page no 391

questions.text: A male present with grouped painful vesicular lesions in the genital area. History of multiple sexual partners present. Irregular use of condoms history present. Smear showed MNGCs. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes genitalis

 

Herpes genitalis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). The presentation of grouped painful vesicular lesions on an erythematous base in the genital area, especially in a patient with a history of multiple sexual partners and irregular condom use, is highly suggestive of herpes genitalis. The presence of multinucleated giant cells (MNGCs) on a smear is a key diagnostic feature of HSV infection. This is because HSV causes the fusion of infected cells, leading to the formation of these giant cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes zoster: Herpes zoster (shingles) typically presents as painful vesicular lesions following a dermatomal distribution, usually on one side of the body. The lesions do not cluster in the genital area unless the sacral nerve is involved, which is uncommon. Also, the absence of a dermatomal pattern makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option C. Warts: Genital warts, caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), present as painless, cauliflower-like growths rather than painful vesicular lesions. The description of painful lesions and the presence of MNGCs on the smear make this option unlikely.

 

Option D. Chancroid: Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents as a painful genital ulcer with ragged edges and undermined borders. It does not present with vesicular lesions or MNGCs on a smear, making this diagnosis incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes genitalis should be considered when a patient presents with grouped painful vesicular lesions in the genital area, especially when there is a history of risky sexual behavior and multinucleated giant cells are observed on a smear.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female is presenting with the special lesions as shown in the below image. What are these lesions called as?

 (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Comedones

 

Comedones are seen in ACNE VULGARIS.

 

ACNE VULGARIS:

 

• Most common form of acne.

• Most characteristic lesion - Comedones.

• Most severe form of acne vulgaris - Grade IV / Nodulocystic Acne.

• Most severe form of acne - Acne conglobata.

 

Comedones (are considered as special lesions) are the specific lesions of acne vulgaris

 

Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne. They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.

 

When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedone or whitehead .

 

When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidised by the air & turns black which is known as open comedone (blackhead)

 

Additional Information

 

 

 

 

According to Global alliance algorithm for acne, Oral isotretinoin is indicated for the treatment of severe acne.

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

Image: global alliance algorithm for improving outcomes in acne

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comedones is identified as small, non-inflamed lesions found in acne, characterized by a plug of sebum and keratin within a hair follicle, presenting as blackheads or whiteheads.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.1, 90.10, 90.13, 90.32 & 90.37

questions.text: A patient presents with a hypopigmented lesion on his back. On examination, there is a complete loss of fine touch and temperature sensation over the lesion. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leprosy

 

Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is characterized by hypopigmented or erythematous lesions with a loss of sensation, which is a hallmark feature. The loss of fine touch and temperature sensation over the lesion indicates nerve involvement, which is typical of leprosy. Specifically, this question points towards tuberculoid leprosy, which is part of the Ridley-Jopling classification. Tuberculoid leprosy presents with a few well-defined hypopigmented lesions that have significant sensory loss due to nerve damage.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option  B. Cutaneous tuberculosis: This condition includes various forms such as lupus vulgaris, scrofuloderma, and tuberculosis verrucosa cutis. These typically present with different skin manifestations like plaques, nodules, or ulcers, not primarily hypopigmented lesions with sensory loss.

 

 

Option  C. Pityriasis alba: This condition commonly affects children and presents as multiple hypopigmented macules, often with fine scaling. There is no associated loss of sensation.

 

 

Option  D. Pityriasis versicolor: A superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species, presenting with hypo- or hyperpigmented patches with fine scaling. The condition does not cause loss of sensation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leprosy should be suspected in patients with hypopigmented or erythematous skin lesions accompanied by a loss of sensation, particularly fine touch and temperature. This sensory loss is due to peripheral nerve involvement, which is a characteristic feature of leprosy.

questions.text: Which nerve is biopsied for the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic leprosy? (AIIMS NOVEMBER 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superficial branch of radial nerve

 

Superficial branch of radial nerve is most commonly used for nerve biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy.

 

Pure neuritic leprosy is characterized by asymmetrical involvement of peripheral nerve trunks without visible skin lesions.

 

  • To confirm the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy, nerve biopsy is considered the gold standard. It is essential to biopsy only sensory nerves and avoid motor or major nerve trunks, as well as mixed nerves.
  • For nerve biopsy in neuritic leprosy, the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is typically utilized.

 

 

  • The biopsy sample should be taken from a purely sensory thickened peripheral nerve, such as the superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve at the wrist, ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border of the base of the hand, or sural nerve near the ankle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve and Option C. Ulnar nerve are less frequently chosen for biopsy in pure neuritic leprosy due to their mixed sensory and motor functions, which could lead to functional deficits if damaged.

 

Option D. Lateral popliteal nerve also known as the common peroneal nerve, is generally avoided in routine nerve biopsies for leprosy due to its deeper location and the significant motor components it controls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the diagnosis of Pure Neuritic Leprosy, the superficial branch of the radial nerve is the preferred site for biopsy due to its accessibility, lower risk of complications, and high diagnostic yield.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.11 28.14

Sensory reanimation of the hand by transfer of the superficial branch of the radial nerve to the median and ulnar nerve - Scientific Figure on ResearchGate. Available from: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Transfer-of-the-superficial-branch-of-the-radial-nerve-SBRN-to-the-median-nerve-MN_fig5_309138539 [accessed 9 Nov, 2023]

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with multiple anogenital warts, and the biopsy reveals squamous atypia. Among the various human papillomavirus types, which ones are classified as high-risk? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HPV 18

 

Explanation:

 

  • Squamous carcinoma is the most prevalent type of cancer associated with HPV infection.
  • Among the various human papillomavirus types, HPV-16 and HPV-18 are considered high-risk and are frequently implicated in the development of cervical, vaginal, and vulval cancers.
  • Other high-risk types include HPV-31, HPV-33, and HPV-35.
  • Genital warts, also known as condyloma acuminata or venereal warts, are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus 6 (HPV-6) and human papillomavirus 11 (HPV-11). These types, referred to as low-risk, have a lower potential to lead to malignancy.

 

Genital warts are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact, although non-sexual transmission is also possible.

 

 

Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are first-line medications prescribed for the treatment of genital warts.

 

IMIQUIMOD:

 

  • Imiquimod cream uses:
    • Actinic keratoses
    • Superficial basal cell carcinoma
    • Genital warts (topical immunomodulation)
       
  • Mechanism of action: Activates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, leading to apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A HPV 2:

  • This type is considered low-risk and is commonly associated with common warts that affect the hands and feet, not with anogenital warts or cancer.

 

Option C & D HPV 6 and HPV 11:

  • These are both low-risk types that are associated with about 90% of genital warts but are not typically linked with cancer.
  • They are known to cause benign conditions like respiratory papillomatosis as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HPV 16 & 18 as high-risk types associated with anogenital cancers, and recognize that HPV 2, 6, and 11 are low-risk types not typically associated with cancer.
  • It’s crucial to know the distinction between low-risk and high-risk HPV types due to the differences in prognosis and management.
  • High-risk types warrant more aggressive monitoring and management due to their association with malignancy.

 

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43, 25.55

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 198

Shaws textbook of gynaecology 16th edition 156, 157, 486

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 650

 

Online resources:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9434721/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK321770/

questions.text: A 27-year-old male came with complaints of asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions and hair loss as given below. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

 

The patient presents with several key clinical features: asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on the trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions (condyloma lata), and patchy hair loss. The patchy hair loss, described as "moth-eaten alopecia," is a characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. These signs are strongly indicative of an infection caused by Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for syphilis. The presence of condyloma lata and the specific type of alopecia observed are classical clues pointing towards this diagnosis.

 

DD of Patchy Alopecia – Alopecia areata, Tinea capitis, Trichotillomania, and Secondary Syphilis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malassezia furfur: This organism is associated with conditions like pityriasis versicolor and seborrheic dermatitis, neither of which typically present with the described combination of symptoms, particularly the moth-eaten alopecia and condyloma lata.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus can cause skin infections and folliculitis, it does not typically cause the type of patchy alopecia or the other systemic symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Microsporum canis: This is a dermatophyte that causes tinea capitis, which can lead to patchy hair loss. However, tinea capitis would be associated with scaly patches and other signs of fungal infection rather than the systemic features like condyloma lata seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "moth-eaten alopecia" is a key diagnostic feature of secondary syphilis, and Treponema pallidum is the causative organism.

questions.text:
Statement 1: Clinically a patient having flaccid bullae with painful erosions, will show Suprabasal split and inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft on histopathological examination.

 

Statement 2: Row of tombstones appearance is diagnostic of Pemphigus vulgaris (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1

 

Both statements are true about Pemphigus vulgaris but statement 2 is not explaining 1.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris, a blistering autoimmune skin condition. The condition is characterized by suprabasal acantholysis (a separation of skin cells above the basal cell layer), leading to the formation of flaccid bullae with painful erosions. The "row of tombstones" appearance describes a specific histological feature of Pemphigus vulgaris.

choices.text: All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic
Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space

questions.text: A 55-year-old female came to the hospital with a history of trauma to the ear. On examination, there is swelling, tenderness, and discoloration of the ear. Which of the following is false regarding the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Resolves spontaneously

 

A hematoma of the auricle is depicted in the image given.

 

The scenario described seems to suggest a case of auricular hematoma, which is a collection of blood in the perichondrial space of the ear, usually following trauma. Here is a breakdown of the options provided:

 

This statement is false regarding Perichondral hematoma . If an Perichondral hematoma is left untreated, it usually does not resolve spontaneously. Instead, it often requires intervention to prevent complications such as infection or the development of 'Cauliflower ear'. The standard treatment involves aspiration of the hematoma or surgical intervention to prevent permanent deformity and to reestablish the connection between the cartilage and the overlying perichondrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotic: While not all cases may strictly require prophylactic antibiotics, they are often administered in practice to prevent infection, especially because the ear cartilage is avascular and therefore more susceptible to infection. The effectiveness of prophylactic antibiotics is debated, but it is a common practice, particularly when there's been a break in the skin.

 

Option B. May lead to Pugilistic ear: This is true. A 'Pugilistic ear' is another term for 'Cauliflower ear', which can occur if an auricular hematoma is not adequately treated, leading to fibrosis and cartilage deformity.

 

Option C. Caused by accumulation of blood in perichondrial space: This is correct. An auricular hematoma occurs when blood accumulates in the space between the cartilage and the perichondrium, which can occur after a blunt trauma to the ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perichondral hematoma (cauliflower ear, wrestler's ear, or pugilistic ear):

 

  • It is a deformity of the ear brought on by repeated trauma.
  • Perichondral space refers to the area of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium.
  • Due to blunt trauma, it is frequently observed in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players.
  • It does not resolve spontaneously.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered in all cases.
  • Under strict aseptic guidelines, aspiration of the hematoma and application of a pressure dressing to stop re-accumulation.
  • Aspiration might have to be done again. Aspiration that doesn't work should be followed by incision and drainage.

 

Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470424/

questions.text: Which of the following differentials should not be considered for the lesion seen in the image developed in a forest officer?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

 

Eschar can be noted in the given image, and Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is not a possible differential diagnosis for eschar.

  • KFD is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic in South India.
  • The primary clinical manifestations of KFD are fever, headache, severe muscle pain, followed by haemorrhagic symptoms like haemorrhages in the skin, mucosa & viscera, petechial lesions are characteristic skin lesions observed.
  • It is more known for its neurological and hemorrhagic manifestations but NOT Eschar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Scrub typhus (chigger-borne typhus)

 

  • The infective agent of scrub typhus, Orientia tsutsugamushi (Previously known as Rickettsia tsutsugamushi), is conveyed to humans from its natural rodent reservoir by the bites of the Trombiculid mite.

 

 

  • Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers.
  • The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The primary lesion, or eschar, is a firm papule up to 1 mm in diameter surmounted by a vesicle, which dries to form a black crust.

 

Option C: Cutaneous anthrax (Hide porters’ disease)

 

  • Anthrax is a zoonotic infection with Bacillus anthracis.
  • Between 1 and 5 days after infection, an irritable papule develops at the site of inoculation. A bulla on a red oedematous base soon follows.
  • The bulla ruptures and forms a haemorrhagic crust which will undergo necrosis. Surrounding this several satellite lesions filled with serum or yellow fluid are arranged around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar.
  • This is called as Malignant pustule as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D: Healing brown recluse spider bite.

 

Bite of Loxosceles reclusa (Loxoscelism) → Target lesion develops → Development of eschar → Heals with Ulcer formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kyasanur Forest Disease tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever, primarily presenting with haemorrhagic and neurological symptoms, should not be considered for skin lesion, Eschar, unlike the other mentioned differentials.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.33

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 249, 250, 415, 530

choices.text: Stop MDT and start oral steroids
Continue MDT and add oral steroids

questions.text: In a pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation, who is currently undergoing multidrug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, she now presents with type 2 lepra reaction. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Continue MDT and add oral steroids

 

To manage a pregnant woman experiencing a type 2 lepra reaction, it is essential to continue the multidrug therapy (MDT) while adding oral steroids as an additional treatment.

 

  • In the management of leprosy, it is crucial to continue multidrug therapy (MDT) to effectively treat the underlying infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae.
  • A Type 2 lepra reaction, also known as erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL), is a complex immunological reaction that occurs in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous leprosy, which can present with painful nodules, fever, malaise, and other systemic symptoms.
  • Oral steroids, such as prednisone, are the treatment of choice for controlling acute inflammatory complications associated with Type 2 lepra reaction. They help reduce inflammation and immune response.
  • It is important to manage the reaction without discontinuing the MDT to prevent the development of drug resistance and further progression of the disease.

 

Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL)

 

  • It is a type 3 hypersensitive immune complex-mediated reaction that affects the skin, nerves, and other organs.
  • It is typically recurrent and commonly observed in individuals with multibacillary leprosy. ENL may occur before treatment, during treatment or after completion of treatment.
  • It is characterized by painful, erythematous nodules appearing on the extensor surfaces of the limbs and face.

 

In a type 2 lepra reaction, systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of fresh skin lesions can be observed.

 

Treatment includes:

 

  • High doses of glucocorticoids are frequently administered to all patients which assist in reducing the acute signs and symptoms of inflammation.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued.
  • Only severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum Leprosum are treated with thalidomide. Thalidomide is gold standard for type II Lepra reaction, but it is NOT the Drug of Choice due to its cost factor & also its Adverse drug reactions profile.

 

Type I & II lepra reactions (ENL= Erythema Nodosum Leprosum):

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop MDT and start oral steroids: Stopping MDT is not advisable because it can lead to the proliferation of Mycobacterium leprae and risk the development of drug resistance.

 

Option B. Antibiotics: While antibiotics are a part of MDT to treat the bacterial infection, they alone are not sufficient to address the acute inflammatory symptoms of a Type 2 lepra reaction.

 

Option C. Thalidomide:

 

  • Thalidomide is an effective treatment for Type 2 lepra reactions due to its potent anti-inflammatory properties.
  • However, it is absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women due to its teratogenic effects, which can cause severe birth defects as seen in the below image.

 

 

Phocomelia

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant woman with leprosy who presents with a Type 2 lepra reaction, the preferred treatment is to continue multidrug therapy and add oral steroids to manage the acute inflammatory symptoms.
  • Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenicity.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.16

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 21st edition page no 1387, 1390

questions.text: Treatment of the male partner is needed in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. When a female is infected with trichomoniasis, she typically presents with symptoms such as green frothy vaginal discharge.

 

Treatment of the female alone is insufficient because if her male partner is not treated, he can reinfect her. This creates a cycle where the infection is passed back and forth between partners. Therefore, treating both partners is essential to break this cycle and prevent reinfection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is not considered a sexually transmitted disease but is due to an imbalance in the vaginal microflora. Treatment of the male partner is not required.

 

Option B. Herpes genitalis: This is caused by the herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2), which produces grouped vesicles over the genitalia. The virus resides in the sacral ganglia and can reactivate under certain conditions, such as immunosuppression. The best advice for couples during active lesions is abstinence from sexual intercourse, but partner treatment is not typically necessary.

 

 

Option C. Candidiasis: This is also not considered a sexually transmitted disease. It results from an overgrowth of Candida species, commonly due to altered vaginal flora. Treatment of the male partner is not required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of the male partner is essential in cases of trichomoniasis to prevent reinfection and break the cycle of transmission.

questions.text: Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is seen in? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Psoriasis

 

Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is most commonly seen in psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin condition.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It is an inflammatory non-infectious disease characterized by an imbalance in T-cell subsets. There is an elevated number of activated Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells, while Th2 cells are deficient.

 

Cytokines in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Genetic predisposition: n Type 1 plaque psoriasis and guttate psoriasis with HLA C:06:02 association.
  • Around 5-30% of individuals with cutaneous psoriasis also develop psoriatic arthritis (PsA), a condition affecting the joints.
  • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
  • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus:

  • Lichen planus can affect the nails and produce nail changes, but the common manifestations are nail thinning, ridging, or even complete loss of the nail.
  • Pterygium formation, where there's scarring of the cuticle area leading to the nail's progressive loss, can also be seen.
  • While lichen planus can cause nail pitting, it's typically not associated with subungual hyperkeratosis, a feature more consistent with psoriasis.

 

Option C. Vitiligo:

  • Vitiligo is a disorder where there's a loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) leading to white patches on the skin.
  • It doesn't typically produce pitting of nails.

 

Option D: Alopecia areata:

Geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of the nails is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriasis is the condition most commonly associated with irregular nail pitting and subungual hyperkeratosis among the options provided.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 4.9, 35.4-35.34, 37.12, 41.1, 41.21 89.28-33

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

choices.text: Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient
Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband
Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present
Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

questions.text: A female patient presents with active genital warts with a history of recurrence, but her husband doesn't have it. What advice will you give to prevent transmission? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Don't involve in intercourse when active lesions are present

 

  • This is the correct answer. Avoiding sexual contact when active lesions are present is one of the most effective ways to prevent the transmission of HPV.
  • Genital warts are primarily caused by specific types of human papillomavirus (HPV-6 and HPV-11).
  • These warts, also known as venereal warts or condyloma acuminata, are highly infectious and are commonly acquired through sexual contact.
  • However, they can also be transmitted through non-sexual means.
  • Genital warts are highly contagious when lesions are active, so abstaining from sexual activity during these times is crucial to prevent spread to partners.

 

 

Management of Genital warts:

 

  • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are the primary drugs recommended as first-line treatments for genital warts. Imiquimod stimulates toll-like receptors 7 and 8, inducing apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells.
  • Imiquimod cream is approved for the treatment of actinic keratoses, superficial basal cell carcinoma, and genital warts through topical immunomodulation
  • The most effective method to prevent the transmission of infection is to abstain from sexual intercourse when active lesions are present.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give continuous prophylaxis to the patient.

 

  • This is not the correct approach because continuous prophylaxis with antivirals is not typically recommended for genital warts, which are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • Antivirals are more commonly used for other viral infections like herpes simplex virus.
  • Moreover, prophylaxis doesn't prevent the transmission of HPV during periods without active lesions.

 

Option B. Give prophylactic antivirals to the husband.

 

  • This option is incorrect for similar reasons as option A. HPV, the virus causing genital warts, does not have a prophylactic antiviral treatment.
  • Furthermore, since the husband does not have active lesions or a history of genital warts, prophylactic treatment is not indicated.

 

Option C. Give antivirals whenever active lesions are present.

 

  • While this might seem like a reasonable approach, it is important to note that antivirals are not effective against HPV.
  • Treatment for active genital warts typically involves topical agents or procedures like cryotherapy, not systemic antiviral medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To prevent the transmission of genital warts caused by HPV, it is advisable to avoid sexual intercourse when active lesions are present, as there are no effective antiviral prophylaxis options for HPV, and HPV transmission risk is highest during periods with active lesions.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 318

Robbins & Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 10 E page no 998

questions.text: A young boy came to Derma OPD with complaints of severe itching at night. On examination, burrows are seen over intertriginous areas, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits. The disease is transmitted by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mite

 

The boy's symptoms, including severe nocturnal itching and the presence of burrows in specific body areas (intertriginous regions, axillae, umbilicus, and between digits), are classic signs of scabies. Scabies is a skin condition caused by infestation with the itch mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis. The mite burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, especially at night. The areas affected (often referred to as the circle of Hebra) are characteristic for scabies.

 

 

Circle of Hebra

 

 

Mites

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Louse: Lice infestation, known as pediculosis, typically causes itching but does not present with burrows in the skin or nocturnal itching. Lice infest hair and clothing rather than burrowing into the skin.

 

Option B. Tick: Ticks are ectoparasites that attach to the skin and can transmit various diseases, such as Lyme disease. However, they do not cause the characteristic burrows or intense nocturnal itching seen in scabies.

 

Option D. Flea: Flea bites cause itchy red spots, primarily on the lower legs, but fleas do not burrow into the skin or cause the described distribution of burrows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scabies is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis, which burrows into the skin, causing intense itching, particularly at night, and burrows in characteristic areas such as the axillae, umbilicus, and between the digits.

questions.text: In a 25-year-old man who visited a primary health center with complaints as shown in the image below, 5 days after engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse. The patient experienced painful ulcers upon palpation, and there was suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy on the right side. Additionally, the patient has no history of drug allergy. What specific kit will be used for managing this sexually transmitted disease? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kit 3/white

 

The clinical image and findings presented above are consistent with chancroid, a sexually transmitted disease.

 

Chancroid:

 

  • The causative agent responsible for chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • The incubation period typically ranges from 3 to 10 days.
  • It is characterized by the presence of painful and deep ulcers, along with tender lymphadenopathy. The recommended kit for managing this condition is Kit 3/White.
  • Initially, a painful papule appears, which later transforms into a painful, non-indurated ulcer with undermined edges, often accompanied by central necrosis.
  • Autoinoculation may lead to the presence of "kissing ulcers."
  • The disease is also associated with painful lymphadenopathy, which can progress to form suppurating sinuses and buboes.
  • When the patient presents with both genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo), it is referred to as concomitant genital ulcer as shown below.

 

Chancroid showing Concomitant genital ulcer: Small soft ulcer on the internal surface of the prepuce with painful, fluctuant inguinal adenitis (bubo).

 

NACO KIT 3 / White color KIT

 

Kit 3/white consists of:

 

  1. Tablet Azithromycin 1gm single dose, which is used for the treatment of chancroid.
  2. Injection Benzathine Penicillin 2.4 Million IU deep IM stat, which is used for syphilis.

 

 

  • Concomitant genital ulcer is seen associated with Chancroid, but absent in LGV.
  • First line treatment for Chancroid is azithromycin 1g orally as a single dose or ceftriaxone 250 mg IM as a single dose.

 

The second-line options for chancroid are as follows:

 

  • Ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice a day for 3 days (OR)
  • Erythromycin base 500 mg orally four times a day for 7 days

 

Differentiating features between Herpes genitalis & Chancroid:

 

 

Other KITs:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When managing a patient presenting with painful genital ulcers and suppurative lymphadenopathy (Bubo), the primary consideration is to treat for chancroid which is a STI, typically with a kit containing appropriate antibiotics.

 

Kit 3/white consists of:

 

  1. Tablet Azithromycin, which is used for the treatment of chancroid.
  2. Injection Benzathine Penicillin, which is used for syphilis.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition, Chapter 30 Page no 30.21
