questions.text: A patient comes with silvery scaly erythematous plaques over extensors with pitting of nails and involvement of scalp is also noted, these findings are consistent with which diagnosis?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Psoriasis vulgaris

 

Psoriasis vulgaris is the most common type of psoriasis.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It an inflammatory non-infectious disease. There is an increased number of activated Th1, Th17 & Th22 cells with a deficiency of Th2 cells.
  • Genetic predisposition is present in type 1 plaque psoriasis & guttate psoriasis with HLA C: 06: 02
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Erythematous plaque with silvery white like scaling.
  • Extensors are commonly involved.
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails. Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter haemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

Pitting affecting the fingernails

 

 

Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis - Mnemonic

 

"Nail - POLISH"

 

• P – Pitting (Most common feature)

• O- Oil drop sign (Pathognomonic), Onycholysis

• L - Leukonychia

• I - Irregular pitting pattern

• S - Splinter Hemorrhage

• H - Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

 

Clinical Sign

 

A defining characteristic of psoriasis is the presence of silvery white, scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the knee and elbow. The Auspitz sign can be used to make a clinical diagnosis of the condition.

 

Scratching (grattage) superficial silvery scales causes them to come off attached, as if one had done so on a wax candle (wax candle scales).

 

The Bulkeley membrane, a thin membrane, can then be seen.

 

When the Bulkeley membrane is removed, the Auspitz sign, a classic pinpoint bleeding, is revealed.

 

The Auspitz sign is the name for the traditional pin-point bleeding.

 

Pin point bleeding spots noted in the below image.

 

 

The Auspitz sign is brought on by elongated, dilated, tortuous vessels in the dermal papillae and supra papillary epidermal thinning.

 

Auspitz Sign is neither sensitive nor specific for psoriasis.

 

Auspitz sign is neither sensitive nor specific for psoriasis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lichen planus:

 

  • Features: It is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by pruritic, flat-topped, polygonal, violaceous papules and plaques. Wickham striae, or fine white lines, can sometimes be seen on the surface of the lesions. Oral involvement is common.

 

Option C. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Features: A rare autoimmune blistering disease of the skin and mucous membranes. Patients develop flaccid bullae or erosions, often with a positive Nikolsky sign (skin slippage with minor friction).
  • Why it doesn't match: The description doesn't mention flaccid blisters or erosions, and the hallmark of pemphigus vulgaris is the presence of these blisters and the positive Nikolsky sign.

 

Option D. Ichthyosis vulgaris

 

  • Features: It's a genetic skin disorder characterized by dry, scaly skin resembling fish scales. The lower legs are often prominently affected, but the condition can also involve the arms, hands, and trunk.
  • Why it doesn't match: While ichthyosis vulgaris can present with scaly skin, it doesn't typically cause erythematous plaques, nail pitting, or specific scalp involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriasis vulgaris by the presence of silvery scaly erythematous plaques predominantly on extensor surfaces, associated with nail pitting and scalp involvement.

 

Reference:  ijdvl.com - Scaly signs in dermatology; Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.4-35.6, 35.9 35.10; Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 333

questions.text: The most specific and typical sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gottron's papules

 

  • Gottron's papules are a characteristic and specific sign seen in juvenile dermatomyositis.
  • The classical diagnostic criteria for Juvenile Dermatomyositis include the presence of Gottron's papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Gottron's papules are identified as violaceous, lichenoid, inflammatory, flat-topped papules found on the extensor surfaces, particularly the knuckles ( proximal interphalangeal joints, distal interphalangeal joints, and metacarpophalangeal joints) as shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Photosensitive skin rash:

 

  • While photosensitivity can be a feature in some patients with juvenile dermatomyositis, it is not the most specific sign.
  • Photosensitive rashes are also common in other conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) making it less specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nail bed capillary changes:

 

  • Nail bed capillary changes, such as dilated or drop-out capillaries, can be seen in juvenile dermatomyositis as shown in the image below

 

 

  • However, these changes are also found in other connective tissue diseases, so they are not the most specific for juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Malar rash:

 

  • A malar rash, or "butterfly rash" as shown in the image below is typically associated with SLE, not juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

 

  • Although skin manifestations can overlap between different connective tissue diseases, a malar rash is not specific to juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gottron's papules are flat-topped, red or violaceous papules. They are considered pathognomonic (specifically indicative) of dermatomyositis and are one of the hallmark features of the disease and represent the most specific sign of juvenile dermatomyositis in a 17-year-old patient.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53, page nos. 53.4, 53.11

Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition Page no 1182, 1183

questions.text: What is the most common causative organism for verruca vulgaris? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Human papillomavirus-2

 

  • The hands, fingers, and knees of young children are the areas that are most frequently affected with common warts.
  • Verruca vulgaris or common wart is most commonly caused by human papillomavirus-2 (HPV-2) but is also related to types 1, 4, 27, and 57.

 

Below image depicts Verruca vulgaris:

 

 

Common warts typically have no symptoms. They appear as firm papules with a rough horny surface and exhibit acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and papillomatosis. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon may be observed.

 

Treatment:

 

Topical – Salicylic acid, formalin, caustics etc.

 

Other:

 

  • Laser
  • Cryotherapy
  • Surgical removal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human papillomavirus-3 (HPV-3): While HPV-3 is a strain of the virus that can cause warts, it is not the predominant strain for verruca vulgaris.

 

Option B. Human papillomavirus-7 (HPV-7):

  • HPV-7 is associated with butcher's warts, which are common among meat handlers.
  • This strain is not the primary one responsible for the verruca vulgaris seen in the general population.

 

Option D. Human papillomavirus-1 (HPV-1): HPV-1 is mainly responsible for plantar warts, which appear on the soles of the feet as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • It is not the primary strain for verruca vulgaris on the hands and fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human papillomavirus-2 is the most common cause of verruca vulgaris (common warts), which is important for understanding the etiology and guiding treatment options for these lesions.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 25, Page no 25.43, 25.47, 25.48, 25.52

Andrew's Diseases of the Skin: Clinical Dermatology - 11th Edition Chapter 19, Page no 401

Online resources:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9434721/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK321770/

questions.text: Structure made up of dense irregular collagen is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermis

 

Dermis (precisely Reticular dermis) is made up of dense irregular connective tissue. 

 

Irregular connective tissue, is characterized by collagen fibers that are randomly oriented in multiple directions.

 

Irregular connective tissue is of three types: Loose, Dense & Adipose.

 

Dense connective tissue can be found in areas where unsheathed organs are protected and where there is significant mechanical stress.

 

  • This arrangement of fibers provides strength and elasticity in multiple directions, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Function: Provides structural integrity and support for the skin.

 

Dense connective tissue:

 

  • It typically exists in the reticular dermis.
  • Muscle and nerve sheaths made of the superficial connective tissue
  • Adventitia of large vessels
  • Capsules of various organs & glands (e.g.: testis sclera, periosteum, perichondrium)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligaments:

 

  • Composition: Primarily made up of dense regular connective tissue, which contains tightly packed collagen fibers that run in parallel directions.
  • Function: Connect bones to other bones.
  • Why it's not the answer: Ligaments have a more organized structure with the collagen fibers aligned in the same direction, which classifies them as dense regular connective tissue.

 

Option C. Tendons:

 

  • Composition: Made up of dense regular connective tissue, with collagen fibers that are closely packed and align in the same direction.
  • Function: Connect muscles to bones, aiding in the transmission of forces and movement.
  • Why it's not the answer: Like ligaments, tendons have collagen fibers that are organized in a parallel manner, making them dense regular connective tissue.

 

Option D. Bones:

 

  • Composition: Hard, dense connective tissue made up of cells (like osteocytes), as well as mineralized extracellular matrix containing collagen fibers and calcium phosphate.
  • Function: Provide structural support, protect vital organs, aid in movement, and store minerals.
  • Why it's not the answer: While bones do contain collagen, their primary structural component is the mineralized matrix which provides rigidity, distinguishing them from the dense irregular connective tissue of the dermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reticular dermis is comprised of the dense irregular connective tissue, that plays a crucial role in providing structural support and integrity to the skin due to its randomly oriented collagen fibers, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.34

Grays Anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice- 42nd edition- page no 40, 41

questions.text:
Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following options: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Alopecia areata
  2. Telogen effluvium
  3. Androgenic alopecia
  4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3

 

Non-scarring alopecia is characterized by hair loss without destruction of the hair follicle, allowing for the potential regrowth of hair. The options provided include three conditions that typically result in non-scarring alopecia:

 

1. Alopecia areata: An autoimmune disorder that causes patchy hair loss on the scalp and other parts of the body. This condition is non-scarring, as the hair follicles are not destroyed and hair can regrow if the underlying autoimmune process is controlled or subsides.

 

2. Telogen effluvium: A condition characterized by widespread thinning of the hair, often triggered by a significant stress event, illness, or hormonal change. It results from a large number of hair follicles entering the resting phase (telogen) simultaneously. Recovery is possible once the triggering event is resolved, and the follicles remain intact.

 

3. Androgenic alopecia: Commonly known as male or female pattern baldness, this is a genetic condition influenced by androgens (hormones). It involves hair thinning in a characteristic pattern and is non-scarring, as the hair follicles gradually produce thinner, shorter hairs but are not completely destroyed.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia is a form of scarring alopecia. It involves a progressive, symmetrical band of hair loss at the front of the scalp along with loss of eyebrows. The scarring means that the hair follicles are permanently destroyed, preventing the regrowth of hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Additional Information

choices.text: Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

questions.text: A farmer visits you with a foot swelling and multiple discharging sinuses in the lower limb. Microscopic examination of granules from the discharge was performed and is as shown in the image below. Based on this information, what can be concluded about this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

 

  • The clinical scenario, along with the presence of sulfur granules in the image, suggests a diagnosis of mycetoma. This condition can be caused by either bacteria (Actinomycetoma) or fungi (Eumycetoma).
  • Mycetoma typically occurs following a trauma, and individuals engaged in agricultural work are at higher risk of developing this condition.

 

 

Clinical features (GST):

 

  1. Grains,
  2. Sinuses,
  3. Tumefaction/swelling

 

The below image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge.

 

 

 

The discharge contains granules which are microcolonies of the causative organism. It is generally more invasive and can spread via the fascial planes (NOT Lymphatic) to the underlying muscle or bone. Dissemination is rare but can occur in lesions of the head and neck.

 

Treatment:

 

  1. Eumycetoma:
    • Antifungals (Itraconazole)
  2. Actinomycetoma:
    • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
    • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is lymphocyte accumulation:

While lymphocytes can be present due to the chronic inflammatory nature of mycetoma, their accumulation is not a distinctive feature of this disease.

 

Option C. Undergoes lymphatic spread:

Mycetoma primarily spreads through contiguous tissue invasion rather than lymphatic spread. This is a feature that differentiates it from other infections like lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option D. Involves only superficial tissues:

This is incorrect because mycetoma can involve both superficial and deep structures, including skin, subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and even bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma can be caused by both bacteria and fungi, and is characterized by the presence of grains in discharging sinuses, often involving deep tissue structures beyond superficial tissues.

 

 

 

Reference –

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 401, 604, 605

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 689

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 1338, 1688

questions.text: Bubo seen in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphogranuloma venereum

 

Explanation:

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3.

 

A bubo refers to an inflamed, swollen lymph node, often filled with pus. In LGV, this typically presents as inguinal lymphadenitis with pus formation, which is a key characteristic feature.

 

 

Another important sexually transmitted disease associated with bubo formation is chancroid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with a painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C. Granuloma inguinale: Also known as donovanosis, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with subcutaneous nodules in the inguinal region but does not involve lymphadenopathy. These nodules are sometimes referred to as pseudo-bubo because of their superficial similarity to buboes, but they do not have the same pathophysiology.

 

Option D. Gonorrhea: Gonorrhea typically presents with urethral discharge and does not cause bubo formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bubo is a characteristic feature of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) and chancroid, involving inflamed, pus-filled lymph nodes, particularly in the inguinal region. ​

questions.text: Match the Dermatological disorders in Column A with their respective investigations in Column B: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

 

Explanation:

 

Correct matches:

 

 

1. Tinea: Tinea infections, also known as dermatophytosis, are fungal infections of the skin, hair, or nails. The diagnosis is commonly made by performing a potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount of skin scrapings, which reveals fungal hyphae under a microscope.

 

2. Lepromatous leprosy: This form of leprosy is diagnosed using a slit skin smear, where a sample from the skin lesion is stained and examined for the presence of acid-fast bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae).

 

 

3. Lupus vulgaris: Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis. The diagnosis often involves a biopsy of the lesion, which shows granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis and the presence of acid-fast bacilli.

 

4. Allergic dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis is diagnosed using a patch test, where suspected allergens are applied to the skin under occlusive patches to observe for a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea is diagnosed with a KOH mount, lepromatous leprosy with a slit skin smear, lupus vulgaris with a biopsy, and allergic dermatitis with a patch test.

questions.text: A 65-year-old guy arrives with tense, itchy bullae over his limbs. The roof of the bullae collapsed after a few days. What is the most likely diagnosis shown in the clinical image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bullous pemphigoid

 

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.

 

  • Elderly aged people are usually affected.
  • It presents as tense itchy bulla, which do not rupture easily, which can have an erythematous base (urticarial wheals) & the roof of the bullae collapses after a few days forming settled bulla, autoantibodies (IgG) against BP180 (BPAG2) and BP 230 (BPAG1) antigens on hemidesmosomes are seen in these patients.
  • It is a subepidermal blistering disorder, so acantholysis will not be seen.
  • Histopathology: subepidermal bullae with eosinophils
  • DIF: deposition of IgG antibodies at the dermo-epidermal junction in a linear pattern.
  • It is mainly treated with Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is another autoimmune blistering disorder. However, the blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid and easily ruptured as shown in the image below, as opposed to the tense bullae seen in bullous pemphigoid. Additionally, the oral mucosa is frequently involved in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

 

Option C. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This condition is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) and presents with itchy papules, vesicles, and bullae. However, the distribution is typically on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees as shown in the image below, and the appearance differs from what is shown in the image in the MCQ.

 

 

Option D. Linear IgA dermatosis: This is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder. The blisters are typically in a "string of pearls" or annular arrangement as shown in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Bullous Pemphigoid is a subepidermal blistering disorder predominantly affecting the elderly, characterized by tense itchy bullae, autoantibodies against BP180 and BP230, and eosinophilic involvement."

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 50, Page no. 50.4-50.37.

questions.text: Which of the following will not commonly present as shown in the image below?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspergillus

 

The image shows a dermatophytic infection in the groin region called as Tinea cruris. Aspergillus species are not dermatophytes & are not associated with tinea infections.

 

This genus of fungi is not commonly involved in tinea infections. Aspergillus species are known to cause various diseases, primarily in the respiratory system, such as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, and invasive aspergillosis. They are not usually responsible for superficial skin infections like the one shown in the image.

 

Annular lesions are ring shaped with central clearing i.e., only the edges are active & appear raised, or in different color. It is present in granuloma annulare and tinea (Dermatophytic infection).

 

 

 

Dermatophytes include 3 genera:

 

  • ﻿﻿﻿Trichophyton species infect skin, hair and nails. E.g., T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc.
  • ﻿﻿﻿Microsporum contains M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. These infect only hair and skin (not nails).
  • ﻿﻿﻿Floccosum is the only species in the genus Epidermophyton, it infects only skin and nails (not hair).

 

Dermatophytes infect and survive only in the dead keratin layers of skin (stratum corneum), hair and nails as they are Keratinophilic.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichophyton:

 

  • Explanation: Trichophyton species are among the most common dermatophytes associated with Tinea cruris. They infect skin, hair, and nails and are known for their role in various forms of tinea, including Tinea cruris.
  • Why it could present as shown: Trichophyton often causes ring-shaped lesions with a clear center and scaly borders, matching the typical presentation of Tinea cruris.

 

Option B. Microsporum:

 

  • Explanation: While Microsporum primarily infects the hair and skin and is less commonly associated with Tinea cruris compared to Trichophyton, it can still cause dermatophytic infections of the groin.
  • Why it could present as shown: Microsporum can cause similar clinical manifestations as Trichophyton in Tinea infections, including red, itchy, and ring-shaped rashes.

 

Option D. Epidermophyton:

 

  • Explanation: Epidermophyton floccosum specifically targets the skin and nails and is a known causative agent of Tinea cruris. This fungus does not infect the hair, differentiating it from some other dermatophytes.
  • Why it could present as shown: Similar to other dermatophytes, Epidermophyton can cause the classic ring-shaped lesions of Tinea cruris with involvement of the groin area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus species do not typically cause superficial skin infections such as tinea cruris; instead, they are more associated with respiratory system conditions. Trichophyton, Microsporum, and Epidermophyton are genera of fungi that commonly cause dermatophytosis like the tinea infections seen in the presented image.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11, 4.13

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.18-20

Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology 9th edition Page no 599

questions.text: Which causative agent is responsible for the 4-year-old boy's condition, characterized by painful mouth sores, a rash on the hands, and fever as shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackievirus

 

The above scenario is suggestive of hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16).CV‐A6 and EV71 are also other important causative organisms.

 

  • Age group commonly affected: Children.
  • Spread: Droplets / fecal contamination.
  • Incubation period: 7 days.
  • Clinical features: In children, the onset is with a low‐grade fever, sore throat and malaise but in adults, a painful stomatitis is an early feature. 
    • Blisters in the mouth soon break down to superficial ulcers.
    • Children are more likely than adults to develop flaccid greyish 2–5 mm oval vesicles on the palms and slightly less frequently on the soles.
  • They fade after 2–3 days. Infection can be subclinical.
  • Only symptomatic treatment is given.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pox virus:

 

  • Poxviruses cause diseases such as smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, which have very different clinical presentations from HFMD.
  • Smallpox, which has been eradicated, presented with a characteristic vesicular and pustular rash and high mortality.
  • Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by firm, painless, umbilicated papules, not the presentation seen in the images provided.

 

Option C. HHV-7 (Human Herpesvirus-7):

 

  • HHV-7 is associated with roseola, a viral infection characterized by a high fever and a rash.
  • HHV 7 is also associated with Pityriasis rosea.
  • However, it does not typically cause painful mouth sores or a rash on the hands.

 

Option D. Parvovirus: Parvovirus B19 can cause a condition called fifth disease, which may result in a rash on the face classically described as slapped cheek appearance as shown in the below image

 

 

but parvo virus not known for causing painful mouth sores or a rash on the hands. Additionally, fifth disease is more common in children between 5 and 15 years old, so it is less likely in a 4-year-old.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of fever, painful oral sores, and a vesicular rash on the hands and feet in a young child is characteristic of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease, which is most commonly caused by Coxsackievirus.

 

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition, Chapter 25 Page no 25.81, chapter 117, Page no 117.6

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1591

questions.text: A male patient complained of bone and joint pain and was prescribed NSAIDs. After a few days, he returned with vesiculo-bullous lesions that subsequently healed, leaving a brownish discoloration on his face (particularly in the upper lip area), as shown in the image. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fixed drug eruption

 

The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of a Fixed drug eruption. Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common forms of drug induced exanthems.

 

A fixed drug eruption is a known adverse drug reaction characterized by recurrent skin eruptions at the same location upon re-exposure to a specific drug. The vesiculo-bullous lesions followed by brownish discoloration can be seen in fixed drug eruptions, making it the most likely diagnosis given the patient's history of NSAID use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the Plasmodium parasite, which is transmitted to humans via the bites of infected Anopheles mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: Fever (often cyclic), chills, sweating, headaches, muscle pains, fatigue, anemia, jaundice due to hemolysis, and enlargement of the spleen.
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: Malaria does not typically cause vesico-bullous lesions or discoloration of the face.

 

Option B. Dengue:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the dengue virus, which is transmitted through the bite of Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: High fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding (e.g., nose or gum bleed, or easy bruising).
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: While dengue can cause rashes, it does not usually result in vesico-bullous lesions or leave a persistent brownish discoloration on the skin.

 

Option C. Chikungunya fever:

 

A strong differential diagnosis is post chikungunya pigmentation (PCP) of the face seen on the nose & cheeks (Chik Sign) as shown in the below image.

 

 

Why it's not the likely diagnosis: However, this is not the answer because there is no antecedent history of fever, myalgia, or other symptoms suggestive of chikungunya. PCP often appears as the fever subsides and may persist for about three to six months. PCP mimics melasma & may be misdiagnosed If proper history is not taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

 

FDE is a drug eruption distinguished by its recurrence at the same sites on re‐challenge with the same drug, hence their site on the skin is fixed, it has a short latency and is benign in nature.

 

FDE typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.

 

  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply‐defined, round or oval erythematous and edematous plaque which evolves to become dusky, violaceous and occasionally vesicular or bullous.
  • Classically hyperpigmentation occurs after lesions heal. Most common cause:
    • NSAIDs - On Lips
    • Cotrimoxazole - On Genitals

 

Acute onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAID's are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 118 page no 118.11, 118.12

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition pages 141-142, 1633

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with a history of chronic and recurrent itchy flexural lesions, considering his family history of asthma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atopic dermatitis

 

The image displays scratch marks and excoriations caused by pruritic lesions at a flexural site. The patient has a personal history of chronic and recurrent course, and there is also a family history of atopy, specifically asthma. These findings suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE).

 

Atopic dermatitis (AD):

 

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that tends to persist or exhibit chronic relapses.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas. Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    3. History of a generally dry skin
    4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
    5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features of AD include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications of AD:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that primarily affects sebum-rich areas of the body such as the scalp, face, and central chest.
  • It's characterized by yellowish, greasy scales and underlying erythema as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • While it can be itchy, its distribution and features are different from the description given.
  • There is no direct association between seborrheic dermatitis and a family history of asthma.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis:

 

  • This results from direct skin contact with allergens. It's an immunological response to a substance the individual has become sensitized to.
  • The lesions would be more correlated with contact to specific allergens, and it's not typically chronic or recurrent unless there is repeated exposure to the same allergen.
  • The distribution would be more in line with areas that contacted the allergen, rather than the typical flexural pattern described.

 

Option D. Erysipelas:

 

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, typically caused by Group A Streptococcus.
  • It presents as a well-demarcated, raised, erythematous, and tender skin lesion, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever.
  • This condition is acute, not chronic or recurrent as described in the scenario.
  • There's no association with a family history of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify atopic dermatitis as a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin disease commonly associated with flexural distribution of eczematous lesions and a family history of atopic conditions, such as asthma.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Online resources:

https://www.jaad.org/article/S0190-9622(13)01095-5/fulltext

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lichen Sclerosus

 

The given image shows Lichen Sclerosus.

 

  • Lichen Sclerosus usually presents in postmenopausal women. Lichen sclerosus is one of the common dermatoses to affect the ano‐genital skin
  • The presenting symptom is usually itching, which is often severe and distressing. Patients may also complain of discomfort and dyspareunia if there is introital narrowing Perianal involvement frequently manifests as a figure-8 shape.
  • White, atrophic papules with abnormal anatomy distortion are the typical appearance. These papules may coalesce into plaques.
  • It is possible for introital stenosis, clitoral concealment, labia minora regression, and urethral obstruction to occur. A biopsy is required to rule out cancer.
  • Topical corticosteroids remain the first line of treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget Disease: Usually manifests as red, scaly, and crusty patches on the vulvar skin as shown in the image below.

 

 

It is often associated with an underlying malignancy. It does not present with white atrophic papules as shown in the question.

 

Option C. Lichen Planus:

 

Presents with purplish, flat-topped, itchy papules and plaques, often with a reticular pattern on mucous membranes, not typically white atrophic papules.

 

Option D. Angioma of Vulva:

 

This would present as a benign growth of small blood vessels and would be red and vascular in appearance as shown below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When encountering white atrophic papules and plaques on the vulva that may coalesce and distort the vulvar anatomy, lichen sclerosus should be considered as a primary diagnosis.

 

Premalignant lesions of vulva:

 

  • Vulvar Intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN)
  • Paget’s disease
  • Lichen sclerosus
  • Condyloma acuminata
  • Bowen disease (Erythroplasia of Queyrat)

 

Ref - William’s gynecology 4th edition Page no 92-100, 688

Shaw’s textbook of gynecology, 17th edition Page no 323, 473-475

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6298145/

questions.text: A child with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phrynoderma

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a child with night blindness and multiple hyperkeratotic papules on the elbows, as depicted in the image, raises suspicion of a diagnosis called phrynoderma or toad-skin. This condition is often linked to a deficiency of vitamin A (VAD).
  • It is characterized by the development of keratotic follicular papules, initially appearing on the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms, and subsequently spreading to the extensor surfaces of the extremities, shoulders, abdomen, back, buttocks, face, and posterior neck.
  • While originally reported in association with vitamin A deficiency, phrynoderma is a non-specific finding that can also be observed in deficiencies of B-complex vitamins, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids (EFA deficiency), protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), and general states of malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratosis pilaris:

  • Description: Keratosis pilaris is a common, benign skin condition that manifests as tiny, rough-feeling bumps on the skin, often likened to "chicken skin." It frequently occurs on the upper arms, thighs, or cheeks.
  • It usually presents during puberty. Perifollicular erythema in addition to follicular plugging
  • Favors the upper outer arms and the thighs, but lacks discrete clusters. Treatment is purely reserved for cosmetic purposes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis:  While keratosis pilaris can appear on the upper arms close to the elbows, it's not specifically associated with night-blindness or vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. Darier disease:

  • Description: Darier disease is a rare, genetic skin disorder characterized by small, hard bumps on the skin, especially on the chest, back, and forehead. These may be yellowish in color and often have a foul odor.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis While Darier disease causes papules, it is not associated with night-blindness. Other features of Darier disease are also not mentioned in the question.

 

Option D. Follicular eczema:

  • Description: This is a variant of eczema (atopic dermatitis) that specifically affects the hair follicles, leading to itchy, inflamed skin.
  • Reasons it might not fit: Though follicular eczema can cause papules, the association with night-blindness is not seen. Eczema would typically be associated with itching and possibly a history of allergies or atopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students preparing for residency, it is crucial to associate the findings of follicular hyperkeratotic papules, especially when coupled with systemic symptoms such as night-blindness, with phrynoderma, a condition related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 63.8

choices.text: Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved
Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected

questions.text: What is correct regarding the diagnosis based on the given image?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

 

The above image shows confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

 

Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a human herpesvirus that causes varicella (chickenpox) as a primary infection and then remains in a latent form in the dorsal root ganglia (NOT Anterior nerve roots) for a variable period after which it can reactivate to cause herpes zoster (shingles) which leads to vesicular lesions that are grouped together in a dermatomal / Segmental distribution as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Herpes zoster:

 

  • Thoracic dermatome is most commonly affected (NOT Trigeminal).
  • The rash is restricted to a dermatome, but sometimes a few chickenpox‐type lesions can be found elsewhere. The lesions are infectious
  • The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.
  • The first symptom of zoster is usually pain, 1-3 days after which the lesions appear. The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx.
  • The dermatomes of T3 to L3 spinal segments are most affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.
  • Zoster is a self-limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post-herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

 

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

 

  1. Painful zoster infections in adults
  2. Facial zoster at any age
  3. Immunocompromised

 

The commonest and most intractable complication of zoster is post-herpetic neuralgia. It is generally defined as persistence or recurrence of pain more than 1-3 months after the onset of zoster. Post-herpetic neuralgia is most frequent when the trigeminal nerve is involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved: False. In herpes zoster, it is the dorsal (posterior) nerve roots and ganglia that are predominantly involved, not the anterior nerve roots. The virus remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia and reactivates there, leading to symptoms in the corresponding dermatomal distribution.

 

Option C. The lesions are not infectious: False. The lesions of herpes zoster are highly infectious, particularly when the blisters are open and the fluid is accessible. The virus contained in these lesions can infect individuals who have not previously had chickenpox or the vaccine, leading to varicella (chickenpox).

 

Option D. Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected: False. While the trigeminal dermatome can be significantly affected (especially concerning due to the risk of herpes zoster ophthalmicus if the ophthalmic branch is involved), it is not the most commonly affected dermatome. The thoracic dermatomes are more frequently involved in herpes zoster cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Herpes zoster, commonly involves reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the dorsal root ganglion, leading to painful cutaneous eruptions that can affect mucous membranes within the involved dermatomes.
  • Herpes zoster lesions are infectious, particularly to those who are not immune to varicella-zoster virus, and thoracic dermatome is the most frequently affected area.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no. 25.27-25.28

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine 20th Edition, Page no 106

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 4.13

choices.text: Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3

questions.text: Bindi Leukoderma is caused by which chemical? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP)

 

Bindi leukoderma is caused by para tertiary butylphenol (PTBP) present in adhesive sticker Bindi.

 

  • This is called contact leukoderma or chemical leukoderma in which the chemical increases sensitivity and induces apoptosis of the melanocytes in the area of contact.
  • There is also evidence that azo dyes, by virtue of structural similarity to tyrosine, can directly inhibit methanogenesis by competing with that amino acid for binding with tyrosinase enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. p-phenylenediamine (PPD): Commonly found in hair dyes and can cause allergic reactions and leukoderma but is not the cause of Bindi leukoderma.

 

Option C. Mono-benzyl ether of Hydroquinone (MBEH): Used in rubber and other synthetic materials to cause depigmentation but not in bindi adhesives.

 

Option D. Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3: Azo dyes used in Alta dye, associated with chemical leukoderma but not specifically with bindi leukoderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP), which is a chemical present in high concentrations in the glue of sticker bindis and is known to cause leukoderma through its melanocytotoxic properties.

 

Common chemicals in Indian setup which can Cause chemical leukoderma are:

 

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 128 page no 128.74

Online source: https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/2965911

Question Level – Intermediate

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he develops fever, malaise, and lesions as seen in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pustular psoriasis

 

The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis.

 

Clinical clues for diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis:

 

  • Pustular Lesions seen after withdrawal of corticosteroids in a psoriasis patient
  • History of fever & malaise
  • Presence of pustules on a circumscribed, fiery red & edematous or scaling plaque

 

Acitretin

 

  • Approved for use in the cutaneous manifestations of psoriasis.
  • It is the DOC for Pustular psoriasis.
  • Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after receiving acitretin treatment to prevent retinoid induced embryopathy.

 

Acitretin:

 

  • Is associated with photosensitivity.
  • It has half-life of 50-70 hours

 

Absolute contraindications:

 

  • Pregnant women
  • Women who are planning to get pregnant
  • Breast-feeding

 

Relative contraindications:

 

  • Leukopenia
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Significant hepatic or renal disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcal infection: While staphylococcal infections can cause skin lesions, there's no direct link provided between steroid withdrawal and the onset of such infections. In fact steroid usage would initiate such staphylococcal infections, not withdrawal.

 

Option C. Acute generalized Exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP): AGEP is typically a reaction to medications not due to steroid withdrawal, and its presentation can be similar to pustular psoriasis.

 

Option D. Sub corneal pustulosis dermatosis: Sub corneal pustular dermatosis is also known as Sneddon-Wilkinson disease. It is a rare condition, characterized by pustules that appear in crops over months or years. However there is no direct link between steroid withdrawal and SCPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient with a history of psoriasis presents with fever, malaise, and widespread pustules following the abrupt withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids, consider pustular psoriasis as the probable diagnosis.
  • This condition can be a severe, life-threatening variant of psoriasis that requires prompt medical attention and management.

 

Ref - Goodman Gillman’s he pharmacological basis of therapeutics – 13th edition page no 1276

Online resources - https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19998529/

Rook’s textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition page no 18.18, 26.22, 35.28, 35.33

questions.text: A patient presents with annular lesions on the skin. Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with annular lesions? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urticaria

 

Explanation:

 

Urticaria, commonly known as hives, is characterized by transient, well-circumscribed, erythematous, and edematous plaques that can be pruritic.

 

 

These lesions typically appear and disappear within a few hours and do not usually form annular (ring-shaped) patterns. Urticaria can be triggered by various factors including allergens, stress, or physical stimuli, but the lesions themselves are generally not annular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea corporis: This is a dermatophyte infection that commonly presents as annular, scaly plaques with a well-defined edge and central clearing. These ring-like lesions are characteristic of tinea infections.

 

 

 

Option B. Porokeratosis: This is a disorder of keratinization that presents with annular plaques with a distinct ridge-like border. The characteristic lesion of porokeratosis is an annular plaque with a raised, ridge-like border and central atrophy.

 

 

Option C. Pityriasis rosea: This condition often begins with a single herald patch followed by the development of multiple oval, scaly lesions that may have a ring or annular appearance. The distribution is often in a Christmas-tree pattern on the back.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urticaria is characterized by transient erythematous plaques that do not typically present as annular lesions, unlike conditions such as tinea corporis, porokeratosis, and pityriasis rosea.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient who is a known case of ovarian cancer presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, combing hair etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dermatomyositis

 

The most probable diagnosis is dermatomyositis. The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis. The clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with a rash in elderly female, with a history of internal malignancy, is also suggestive of dermatomyositis

 

The following list includes several dermatomyositis symptoms:

 

  • Heliotrope rash around eyelids with a lilac hue.
  • Gottron's papules are violaceous, erythematous papules that can appear over the elbow, knee, dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.
  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution)
  • Nail fold changes with periungual erythema with visible dilated capillary loops in the proximal nail fold
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual labourer
  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Screening:  Approximately 20 to 40% of patients have an underlying malignancy (eg, lung, ovarian, breast) and hence screening should be done at the time of diagnosis.

 

Diagnosis:  Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Gottron's papule, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign are associated with anti-Mi2 antibodies.

 

Mechanics hand, Myositis, and ILD (Interstitial Lung Disease) are associated with anti-histidyl tRNA synthetase (anti-Jo-1) antibodies.

 

Prognosis: The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • Features: SLE is an autoimmune disorder characterized by a malar "butterfly" rash, arthritis, and a variety of systemic symptoms. It can affect multiple organs, including the skin, kidneys, and nervous system.
  • Why it doesn't match the clinical vignette given in the MCQ: While muscle pain and inflammation can be a part of SLE, the described presentation with a clear muscle weakness pattern, especially in the context of ovarian cancer, is more suggestive of dermatomyositis.

 

Option C. Systemic sclerosis:

 

  • Features: Systemic sclerosis (or scleroderma) primarily affects the skin, leading to thickening and hardening. It can also cause problems in blood vessels, the digestive tract, and other internal organs.
  • Why it doesn't match the clinical vignette given in the MCQ: While systemic sclerosis can affect various organs and can cause muscle weakness indirectly due to skin tightening, the described presentation is more specific to dermatomyositis.

 

Option D. Cushing syndrome:

 

  • Features: Cushing syndrome is caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. Symptoms include weight gain, purple striae on the skin, facial puffiness, and thinning of the skin.

 

 

Cushing syndrome: Striae seen

 

  • Why it doesn't match the clinical vignette given in the MCQ: While muscle weakness can be a symptom of Cushing syndrome, the absence of other hallmark features and the association with ovarian cancer make dermatomyositis a more likely diagnosis in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermatomyositis is diagnosed by the presence of heliotrope rash, Gottron's papules, and proximal muscle weakness, and consider its association with underlying malignancies in adult patients.

 

Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Page no 53.5, 53.6 and 53.8, 56.12-15

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition page no 2914

questions.text: A female presented in dermatology OPD with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best step among the following options? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Evaluate for hyperandrogenism

 

  • Since the patient is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy, syndromes associated with acne should be evaluated and ruled out to reach a diagnosis. One of the important syndrome is HAIR-AN syndrome.
  • Hence, the next best step would be to evaluate for hyperandrogenism.

 

Important Syndromes Associated with Acne:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Looking for dietary triggers: It could be considered, but this should already be taken care of before prescribing isotretinoin and antibiotics.

 

Option C. Checking for antibiotic resistance: This seems an appropriate step but can’t prioritize over ruling out HAIR-AN syndrome in this patient.

 

Option D. Drug triggers are unlikely to be the primary cause of acne patient who is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. Moreover, lesions in Drug-induced acne are monomorphic and comedones are absent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When faced with a female patient whose acne has not improved with oral isotretinoin and antibiotics, the next best step is to evaluate for hyperandrogenism, which can point to an underlying hormonal cause such as PCOS, necessitating a different treatment approach.

 

References: Williams Gynaecology 4th edition: page no 392-394

questions.text: Match the following therapeutic methods used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

Correct matches

 

 

PUVA (Psoralen and Ultraviolet A)

 

  • Over 90% of cases of psoriasis are successfully treated with PUVA.
  • Both acute (erythema, blistering) and chronic side effects are associated with it.
  • Use of PUVA for an extended period is linked to non-melanoma skin cancer development (squamous cell and basal cell cancers).

 

Cyclosporine

 

  • Cyclosporine usage is primarily linked to metabolic issues, a possible increased risk of malignancy, and renal impairment (decreased GFR).
  • Due to its nephrotoxic effects, it is now uncommonly used for the maintenance of psoriasis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common therapies for psoriasis with their potential side effects:

 

  • PUVA increases the risk of skin cancer (1-c),
  • Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic (2-b),
  • Methotrexate can act as an abortifacient (3-a), and
  • Acitretin is teratogenic and can cause mucositis (4-d).

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.26-28

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 3402

questions.text: The 20-year-old young female presented to the OPD with the following forehead lesions. Which of the following methods won't help with the treatment of various stages of this condition? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical fluocinolone

 

The patient's age and the presence of comedones on the face are suggestive of acne. With the exception of topical fluocinolone (a topical steroid), all of the aforementioned treatments are effective for treating acne. Regardless of how they are administered (Topical or oral).

 

Topical fluocinolone is a corticosteroid. While it may reduce inflammation, its use is not recommended for acne as it can exacerbate the condition, potentially causing acneiform eruption or steroid acne. Steroids can also lead to skin thinning and other adverse effects when used on the face for extended periods.

 

  • Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne,
  • They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.
  • When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedones or whitehead.
  • When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidized by the air & turns black which is known as open comedones (blackhead).

 

Stages of acne:

 

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical benzoyl peroxide:

 

  • This is a commonly used treatment for acne. Its mechanism of action includes reducing Propionibacterium acnes (a bacteria contributing to acne) colonization and producing an oxidizing effect which reduces inflammation.
  • It is effective and is commonly used either alone or in combination with other treatments.

 

Option C. Topical tazarotene:

 

  • Tazarotene is a topical retinoid. Retinoids are vitamin A derivatives that help unclog pores by promoting the shedding of dead skin cells from the surface of the skin and reducing inflammation.
  • They are effective in treating both non-inflammatory and inflammatory acne lesions.

 

Option D. Topical antibiotics:

 

  • These help in reducing the P. acnes bacterial count, which subsequently reduces inflammation.
  • Commonly used topical antibiotics include clindamycin and Nadifloxacin.
  • They may be used alone or in combination with other agents, such as benzoyl peroxide, to reduce bacterial resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical fluocinolone, a corticosteroid, can reduce inflammation, but it is not recommended for acne treatment as it can exacerbate the condition.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.1-90.37

questions.text: The histopathology picture below is suggestive of? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • The given slide shows a row of tombstones' appearance, which is classically seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • The production of antibodies, specifically those against Desmoglein 3, is seen in Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Desmoglein 1 antibodies are also occasionally associated.

 

 

  • Usually, the antibodies are IgG antibodies. The skin and mucosa's basal and suprabasal layers contain the majority of Desmoglein 3.
  • Hemidesmosomes help in connecting basal layer to underlying dermo-epidermal junction, in pemphigus vulgaris there are no antibodies against Hemidesmosomes, so the basal layer remains attached to the underlying dermo-epidermal junction giving the classical Row of tombstones appearance.
  • The patients, therefore, present with flaccid bullae over the skin and due to Desmoglein 3 involvement, mucosal involvement can also be seen.
  • Oral mucosa is commonly affected.

 

 

  • Other areas where ulceration can be seen are conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, etc.
  • Cutaneous lesions are more common over the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back as seen in the image below.

 

 

Biopsy: The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones.

 

 

IMAGE of row of tombstones appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Psoriasis vulgaris:

 

  • This is an autoimmune disease characterized by hyperproliferation of keratinocytes leading to thickened, scaly plaques.
  • Histologically, it shows parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum), elongation of rete ridges, and a neutrophilic infiltrate (Munro's microabscesses) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not a feature of psoriasis.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis:

 

  • It's a parasitic infection caused by the Leishmania species.
  • Histologically, it is characterized by macrophages containing the parasite (Leishman-Donovan bodies) in the dermis as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The tombstone appearance is not seen in leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Mycosis fungoides:

 

  • This is a type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma.
  • Histologically, there is an atypical lymphocytic infiltrate in the epidermis (epidermotropism), and the formation of Pautrier's microabscesses (collections of lymphocytes in the epidermis) as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It does not exhibit a tombstone appearance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histopathology image suggests Pemphigus vulgaris, which is characterized by intraepidermal blistering due to acantholysis, or separation of keratinocytes, as a result of autoantibody attack on desmosomal proteins.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 50 Page no 50.1

Robbins & cotran Pathologic Basis of disease 10e- page no 1160

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below which is characterized by development of morphologically similar lesions along the lines of trauma:  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isomorphic phenomenon

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso(same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

Darier’s disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma & lichen nitidus.

 

Reverse Koebner phenomenon or Renbeok phenomenon:

 

Seen in psoriasis. The area of psoriasis clears & heals following injury (trauma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Gottron's papule seen associated with Dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nikolsky Sign

 

Description: Positive when the superficial epidermis moves laterally with slight rubbing or pressure, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the underlying dermis as shown in the below image.

 

 

 

Option D: Meyerson phenomenon is a melanocytic nevus that has developed an eczematous ring around it as seen in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isomorphic phenomenon (Koebner phenomenon) as the appearance of skin lesions similar to a primary disease along areas of skin trauma, which is important for diagnosis and management in dermatology.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 123.2

questions.text: The following image depicts which of the following diseases? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scabies

 

Special linear tunnel like lesion called Burrow; is depicted in the image given and it is seen in Scabies. Burrow is the pathognomonic lesion of scabies. Usually, S shaped.

 

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused by the Sarcoptes scabei var hominis.

 

Itch mite

 

Sarcoptes scabei

 

 

  • The incubation period of scabies typically lasts 3-4 weeks (21-28 days). However, in previously cured individuals, reinfection can lead to immediate symptoms.
  • The most common symptom associated with scabies is nocturnal pruritus, and the itching worsens at night and in warm conditions.
  • Scabies is considered a water-washed disease, meaning it is linked to inadequate personal hygiene and limited access to clean water.
  • Distinctive signs of scabies include intense itching and the presence of shallow burrows.

 

Burrows in scabies are typically found in the stratum corneum as depicted in the below image.

 

 

In most people the trails of the burrowing mites appear brownish linear or s shaped tracks in the skin & occur as a result of excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis.

 

S-shaped track, pointed with black arrows in the below image:

 

 

  • Burrows are absent in animal scabies.
  • Lesions are found in the Circle of Hebra (imaginary line formed by connecting the sites of involvement in scabies like, web spaces, feet, ventral wrists, elbows, cack, breasts, buttocks & external genitals).
  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults & from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old & pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ichthyosis:

 

  • Ichthyosis is a group of skin disorders characterized by dry, scaly skin.
  • It does not have burrowing mites, hence no burrows are seen.
  • It generally presents with large scales, especially on the lower limbs.

 

Option C. Contact dermatitis:

 

  • This is an allergic or irritant-induced skin inflammation.
  • It manifests as red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with vesicles or blisters.
  • There's no mite involvement or formation of burrows in contact dermatitis.

 

Option D. Urticaria:

 

  • Commonly known as hives, urticaria presents as raised, itchy, red lesions on the skin.
  • It is an allergic reaction and can be triggered by a variety of factors.
  • Urticaria does not involve mites or the creation of burrows in the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of linear tunnel like lesions called as burrows in the stratum corneum of the skin, as depicted in the image, is a hallmark sign of scabies, distinguishing it from other skin conditions like ichthyosis, contact dermatitis, and urticaria.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.39-34.47

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no: 3274

questions.text: A child with a sore throat/upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) started developing skin lesions after treatment with Amoxiclav as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Guttate psoriasis

 

Guttate psoriasis is commonly triggered by a preceding streptococcal infection, such as a sore throat or URTI. The hallmark of guttate psoriasis is the sudden onset of small, droplet-shaped, erythematous papules, which are scattered predominantly over the trunk, although they can also appear on the limbs. The description of the skin lesions as "raindrop-like" in appearance over the trunk, coupled with the history of a sore throat, strongly suggests guttate psoriasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pustular psoriasis: This type of psoriasis is characterized by the presence of sterile pustules on an erythematous background. It can be triggered by the abrupt withdrawal of systemic steroids. The condition typically presents with widespread pustules rather than small papules, making it less likely in this case.

 

 

Option C. Erythrodermic psoriasis: Erythrodermic psoriasis involves more than 90% of the body surface area and is characterized by widespread erythema and scaling. It is a severe and potentially life-threatening form of psoriasis that does not match the presentation of small, discrete papules seen in this patient.

 

 

Option D. Inverse psoriasis: Inverse psoriasis presents in skin folds such as the axilla, groin, under the breasts, and other flexural areas. The lesions are usually erythematous and lack the scaling typically seen in other forms of psoriasis. The distribution and type of lesions described here do not correspond to inverse psoriasis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guttate psoriasis is often precipitated by a streptococcal throat infection and presents with multiple, small, droplet-like erythematous papules primarily over the trunk.

questions.text: After using a hair dye a lady developed a skin reaction as shown in the image. Which of the following chemicals among given options is responsible for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Para-Phenylenediamine

 

The history of hair dye use and above image points to a diagnosis of contact dermatitis due to an allergen called Para phenylenediamine.

 

Contact Dermatitis is of 2 types:

 

 

Diagnosis of Allergic CD – PATCH TEST

 

Examples of Allergic CD:

 

  1. Hair dye: PPD (para phenylenediamine)
  2. Metal: Nickel (most common)
  3. Topical antibiotic: Neomycin
  4. Cement: Potassium dichromate
  5. Bindi: PTBP (para tertiary butyl phenol)

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pollen:

 

  • Pollen is a common allergen that can cause allergic reactions in some individuals.
  • However, the use of hair dye does not typically involve exposure to pollen, so it is unlikely to be the cause of the skin reaction in this context.

 

Option B. Chromates:

 

  • Chromates, particularly hexavalent chromium compounds, can be found in some industrial processes and certain products.
  • While exposure to chromates can cause skin reactions in some cases, they are not commonly found in hair dyes, so they are less likely to be the cause here.

 

Option C. Balsam of Peru:

 

  • Balsam of Peru is a known allergen found in various cosmetics and fragrance products.
  • It can cause allergic contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals.
  • If the hair dye contains Balsam of Peru, it could be a potential allergen, but it is not as commonly associated with hair dye allergies as PPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Para-Phenylenediamine (PPD) is a common cause of allergic contact dermatitis (delayed hypersensitivity reaction) associated with hair dye use.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition: 89.73 128.15, 128.42, 128.60

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary skin lesion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Purpura

 

Purpura is a primary skin lesion. It is a disorder that causes red or purple areas on the skin that do not blanch when pressure is applied. RBC extravasation into the skin is the reason for these red patches.

 

It occurs under the following circumstances:

 

  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Crust: A secondary lesion that forms when serum, blood, or other exudates dry on the skin surface.

 

Option B: Atrophy: A secondary lesion characterized by a thinning of any part of the skin due to loss of collagen, elastin, or fat.

 

Option D: Induration: A secondary change resulting in the hardening of the skin, often due to an inflammatory response or chronic disease affecting deeper layers like the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

 

Additional Information

 

Primary lesions of the skin include:

 

  • Papule Plaque Nodule
  • Vesicle Bulla
  • Macule Patch
  • Pustule Abscess
  • Petechiae Purpura Ecchymosis
  • Wheal

 

Primary Lesion:

 

1. Flat Lesions (Neither raised Nor Depressed)

 

 

2. Circumscribed solid raised lesions

 

 

3. Clear fluid filled lesions

 

 

4. Pus filled lesions

 

 

5.  Wheal

 

 

6.  Extravasation of RBC→ Skin/Mucosa

 

 

Secondary lesions of the skin include:

 

  • Lichenification 
  • Atrophy
  • Ulcer
  • Erosion
  • Excoriation
  • Crust
  • Induration
  • Scar 
  • Fissure
  • Scale

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purpura is a primary skin lesion indicative of an underlying vascular or coagulation disorder, differentiating it from secondary skin lesions such as crusts, atrophy, and induration, which result from external factors or the progression of skin diseases is also crucial.

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 4 page no 4.10

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7437 Unique Key-Q1311505

questions.text: What is the likely cause of a disease that is characterized by the occurrence of blistering and peeling affecting over 30% of the body surface area? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drugs

 

Adverse drug reactions can lead to a condition known as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) or its more severe form, Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN), where there is extensive detachment of the epidermis and mucous membrane involvement. This severe reaction typically involves over 30% of the body surface area in TEN. It is a medical emergency and can be life-threatening. The implicated drugs often include allopurinol, certain anticonvulsants, sulphonamide antibiotics, and NSAIDs, among others.

 

As more than 30% of the body surface is involved, the diagnosis is toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Clinical picture will be as shown in the image below.

 

 

SJS Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis classification based on BSA involvement:

 

Based on body surface area (BSA):  

 

 

SJS/TEN is primarily a drug‐induced phenomenon, with a culprit drug being demonstrated in approximately 85% of cases.

 

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN are:

 

  • Allopurinol
  • Carbamazepine
  • Lamotrigine
  • Nevirapine
  • Oxicam (Non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs)
  • Phenobarbital
  • Phenytoin
  • Sulfamethoxazole and other sulfa antibiotics
  • Sulfasalazine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral Infection: Viral infections can indeed cause skin rashes and even blistering in some cases, such as with herpes viruses, including Varicella-zoster virus and Herpes simplex virus. However, they rarely lead to a condition with widespread blistering affecting over 30% of the body surface area.

 

Option C. Fungal Infection: Fungal infections typically cause localized skin changes such as rashes, scaling, and sometimes blistering, but these are usually limited in scope and do not affect such a large proportion of the skin surface as described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Auto-immunity: Autoimmune diseases like pemphigus vulgaris can cause blistering, but they do not usually result in acute widespread skin peeling over 30% of the body surface area. The blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are more superficial and often rupture easily, not typically resulting in extensive peeling.

 

In conclusion, when presented with widespread blistering and peeling of such a significant portion of the skin, drug reactions should be the first consideration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The occurrence of blistering and peeling affecting over 30% of the body surface area is most commonly associated with severe drug reactions, such as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) or Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN).

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition, Chapter 119, Page no 119.13
